direction.raw_text: & GRILLE, SOUTH BOSTON -- EVENING The bar is dirty, more than a little run down. If there is ever a cook on duty, he's not here now. As we pan across several empty tables, we can almost smell the odor of last nights beer and crushed pretzels on the floor.

direction.raw_text: As the camera rises, we find FOUR YOUNG MEN seated around a table near the back of the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guy holding court is CHUCKIE SULLIVAN, 20, and the largest of the bunch. He is loud, boisterous, a born entertainer. Next to him is WILL HUNTING, 20, handsome and confident, a softspoken leader. On Will's right sits BILLY MCBRIDE, 22, heavy, quiet, someone you definitely wouldn't want to tangle with. Finally there is MORGAN O'MALLY, 19, smaller than the other guys. Wiry and anxious, Morgan listens to Chuckie's horror stories with eager disgust. All four boys speak with thick Boston accents. This is a rough, working class Irish neighborhood and these boys are its product.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuckie is really laughing now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morgan gives Will a look, but Will only smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The opening credits roll over a series of shots of the city and the real people who live and work there, going about their daily lives. We see a panoramic view of South Boston. Will sits in his apartment, walls completely bare. A bed, a small night table and an empty basket adorn the room. A stack of twenty or so LIBRARY BOOKS sit by his bed. He is flipping through a book at about a page a second. Chuckie stands on the porch to Will's house. His Cadillac idles by the curb. Will comes out and they get in the car. We travel across crowded public housing and onto downtown. Finally, we gaze across the river and onto the great cementdomed buildings that make up the M.I.T. campus. CUT TO:

dialogue.raw_text: I was thinking about what you said to me the other day, about my painting. I stayed up half the night thinking about it and then something occurred to me and I fell into a deep peaceful sleep and haven't thought about you since. You know what occurred to me?

dialogue.raw_text: You're just a boy. You don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about.

dialogue.raw_text: No.

dialogue.raw_text: So if I asked you about art you could give me the skinny on every art book ever written... Michelangelo? You know a lot about him I bet. Life's work, criticisms, political aspirations. But you couldn't tell me what it smells like in the Sistine Chapel. You've never stood there and looked up at that beautiful ceiling. And if I asked you about women I'm sure you could give me a syllabus of your personal favorites, and maybe you've been laid a few times too. But you couldn't tell me how it feels to wake up next to a woman and be truly happy. If I asked you about war you could refer me to a bevy of fictional and non-fictional material, but you've never been in one. You've never held your best friend's head in your lap and watched him draw his last breath, looking to you for help. And if I asked you about love I'd get a sonnet, but you've never looked at a woman and been truly vulnerable. Known that someone could kill you with a look. That someone could rescue you from grief. That God had put an angel on Earth just for you.  And you wouldn't know how it felt to be her angel. To have the love be there for her forever. Through anything, through cancer. You wouldn't know about sleeping sitting up in a hospital room for two months holding her hand and not leaving because the doctors could see in your eyes that the term "visiting hours" didn't apply to you. And you wouldn't know about real loss, because that only occurs when you lose something you love more than yourself, and you've never dared to love anything that much. I look at you and I don't see an intelligent confident man, I don't see a peer, and I don't see my equal. I see a boy. Nobody could possibly understand you, right Will? Yet you presume to know so much about me because of a painting you saw.  You must know everything about me.  You're an orphan, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think I would presume to know the first thing about who you are because I read "Oliver Twist?" And I don't buy the argument that you don't want to be here, because I think you like all the attention you're getting. Personally, I don't care. There's nothing you can tell me that I can't read somewhere else.  Unless we talk about your life. But you won't do that. Maybe you're afraid of what you might say.

dialogue.raw_text: My wife used to turn the alarm clock off in her sleep. I was late for work all the time because in the middle of the night she'd roll over and turn the damn thing off. Eventually I got a second clock and put it under my side of the bed, but it got to where she was gettin' to that one too. She was afraid of the dark, so the closet light was on all night. Thing kept me up half the night.  Eventually I'd fall asleep, out of sheer exhaustion and not wake up when I was supposed to cause she'd have already gotten to my alarms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My wife's been dead two years, Will. And when I think about her, those are the things I think about most. Little idiosyncrasies that only I knew about.  Those made her my wife. And she had the goods on me too. Little things I do out of habit. People call these things imperfections Will. It's just who we are. And we get to choose who we're going to let into out weird little worlds. You're not perfect. And let me save you the suspense, this girl you met isn't either. The question is, whether or not you're perfect for each other. You can know everything in the world, but the only way you're findin' that one out is by giving it a shot. You sure won't get the answer from an old fucker like me. And even if I did know, I wouldn't tell you.

direction.raw_text: & GRILLE -- LATER Skylar and Will sit together along with Will's gang. The boys are considerably drunk, but it makes for good entertainment. Everyone here is having fun including Sylar.

dialogue.raw_text: Two weeks? That's nothin'. My Uncle Marty? Will knows him. That guy fuckin' drinks like you've never seen! One night he was drivin' back to his house on I-93 -- Statie pulls him over.

dialogue.raw_text: Oh shit.

dialogue.raw_text: Guy's tryin' to walk the line -- but he can't even fuckin' stand up, and so my uncle's gonna spend a night in jail.  Just then there's this fuckin' BOOM like fifty yards down the road. Some guy's car hit a tree.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, he was probably drunker than my Uncle, who fuckin' knows? So the cop goes "Stay here" And he goes runnin' down the highway to deal with the other crash. So, my Uncle Marty's standin' on the side of the road for a little while, and he's so fuckin' lit, that he forgets what he's waitin' for. So he goes, "Fuck it." He gets in his car and drives home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Holy shit.

dialogue.raw_text: So in the morning, there's a knock on the door it's the Statie. So my Uncle's like, "Is there a problem?" And the Statie's like "I pulled you over and you took off."  And my Uncle's like "I never seen you before in my life, I been home all night with my kids." And Statie's like "Let me get in your garage!" So he's like "All right, fine." He takes around the garage and opens the door -- and the Statie's cruiser is in my Uncle's garage.

dialogue.raw_text: No way! You're kiddin'!

dialogue.raw_text: No, he was so hammered that he drove the police cruiser home. Fuckin' lights and everything!

dialogue.raw_text: And he comes across a bottle, and this Genie pops out. The genie turns to the Irishman and says -- "You've released me from my prison, so I'll grant you three wishes." The Irish guy thinks for a minute and says "What I really want is a pint of Guiness that never empties."  And -- POOF! A bottle appears. He slams it down, and -- lo and behold -- it fills back up again.

The Irish guy slams his drink again, it fills back up, he's still amazed. The Genie can't take it anymore. He says "Buddy, I'm boiling out here. What are your other two wishes?" (beat) The Irish guy looks at his drink, looks at the Genie and says... "I guess I'll have two more of these."

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't about me. I'm nothing compared to this young man. (beat) Sean, in 1905 there were hundreds of Professors who were renowned for their study of the universe. But it was a 26-year-old Swiss Patent clerk, doing physics in his spare time, who changed the world, Sean. Can you imagine if Einstein had given that up? Or gotten drunk with his buddies in Vienna every night? All of us would have lost something. And I'm quite sure Timmy never would have heard of him.

I was doing advanced mathematics at eighteen and it still took me twenty-three years to do something worthy of a Field's medal.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, you took one road and I took another. That's fine.

dialogue.raw_text: Is it Gerry? 'Cause I don't think it's fine with you. Give him time to figure out what he wants.

dialogue.raw_text: That's a wonderful theory, Sean. It worked wonders for you.

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you know where to find me?

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) You were the only Sullivan in the phone book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will and I dropped you off here, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is your house, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Get in here, Chuckie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (calling back) Pipe down, Ma!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? No. This is my mother's house. I don't live with my mother. I just stop by, help out. I'm good like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this a bad time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She'll live. (beat) If she starts yelling again I might have to run in real quick and beat her with the stick again but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's take a walk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CHUCKIE'S STREET -- DAY Chuckie, still in his boxers walks with Skylar who is talking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: See, now this doesn't feel right. (beat) When I made the decision to come over here it felt right. I had all these rationalizations... I just don't understand why Will never tells me anything, he won't let me get close to him, he tells me these weird lies--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You caught that, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just wanted to find out what was going on... But now that I'm here it seems strange, doesn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I don't have no trousers on...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know why you're here. Will don't talk much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care what his family's like or if he doesn't have any brothers, but he doesn't have to lie to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really don't know what to say. Look, I lie to women all the time. That's just my way. (beat) Last week Morgan brought these girls down from Roslindale. I told them I was a cosmonaut. They believed me. But Will's not usually like that--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put some clothes on, Sullivan!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it easy father!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I can say is; I known Will a long time -- And I seen him with every girl he's ever been with. But I've never seen him like this before, ever with anyone, like how he is with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LAMBEAU'S OFFICE -- DAY Tom and Will are sitting waiting for Lambeau.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lambeau enters going over a thick proof Will has completed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will gets up to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will turns around reveling that he's lit the PROOF ON FIRE. Will drops it on the floor. Lambeau drops to his knees and puts it out. He looks up at Will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lambeau gathers his composure and calmly walks over to the wrinkled proof. He picks it up, smooths it out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is correct. I see you used Mclullen here--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what it's called.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: --This can't be right. (examining proof) This is going to be very embarrassing. Have you ever considered--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm pretty sure it's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning back) Can I ask you a favor, can we do this at Sean's from now on? 'Cause I leave work to come here and the fuckin' commute is killin' me--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's fine, but did you ever think--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's right. (a beat, heading out) Take it home with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will, what happened at the Tri-tech meeting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't go 'cause I had a date. So I sent my chief negotiator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will, on your own time, you can do what you like. When I set up a meeting, with my associates, and you don't show up it reflects poorly on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then don't set up any more meetings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll cancel every meeting right now. I'll give you a job myself. I just wanted you to see what was out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I don't want to spend my life sittin' around and explaining shit to people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The least you can do is show me a little appreciation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicates proof) You know how fuckin' easy this is to me? This is a joke! (crumples proof) And I'm sorry you can't do this. I really am. 'Cause if you could I wouldn't be forced to watch you fumble around and fuck it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, then you'd have more time to sit around and get drunk. Think of how many fights you could have been in by now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right, Will. I can't do that proof and you can. And when it comes to this there are only twenty people in the world that can tell the difference between you and me. But I'm one of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So am I. (beat) Yes. That's right, Will. Most days I wish I never met you. Because then I could sleep at night. I wouldn't have to walk around with the knowledge that someone like you was out there. And I wouldn't have to watch you throw it all away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SKYLAR'S ROOM -- NIGHT Will and Skylar lie in bed. Skylar watches Will sleep. She gets up and goes to the fridge. Returning to the bed:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will lifts his shirt, revealing a six inch SCAR on his torso.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will, full of self-loathing, raises his hand to strike her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Will looks Skylar dead in the eye. Lowers his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Will? Are you awake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come with me to California.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to come with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. I just do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, but how do you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I just feel it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're sure about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I'm sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Cause that's a serious thing you're sayin'. I mean, we might be in California next week and you could find out somethin' about me that you don't like. And you might feel like "hey this is a big mistake." (getting upset) But you can't take it back, 'cause you know it's real serious and you can't take somethin' like that back. Now I'm in California, 'cause you asked me to come. But you don't really want me there. And I'm stuck in California with someone who really doesn't want me there and just wishes they had a take-back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "Take-back?" What is that? I don't want a take-back. I want you to come to California with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't go out to California.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One, because I have a job here and two because I live here--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Look, Will if you're not in love with me, you can say that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sayin' I'm not in love with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what are you afraid of?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean "What am I afraid of?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why won't you come with me? What are you so scared of?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What am I scared of?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what aren't you scared of? You live in your safe little world where nobody challenges you and you're scared shitless to do anything else--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me about my world. You're the one that's afraid. You just want to have your little fling with the guy from the other side of town and marry--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that what you think--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: some prick from Stanford that your parents will approve of. Then you'll sit around with the rest of the upper crust kids and talk about how you went slummin' too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I inherited that money when I was thirteen, when my father died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least you have a mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you! You think I want this? That money's a burden to me. Every day I wake up and I wish I could give that back.  I'd give everything I have back to spend one more day with my father. But that's life. And I deal with it. So don't put that shit on me. You're the one that's afraid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck am I afraid of?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're afraid of me. You're afraid that I won't love you back. And guess what?  I'm afraid too. But at least I have the balls to it give it a shot. At least I'm honest with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not honest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about your twelve brothers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, is that what this is about? You want to hear that I don't really have any brothers? That I'm a fuckin' orphan? Is that what you want to hear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Will. I didn't even know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you don't want to hear that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I do, Will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to hear that I got cigarettes put out on me when I was a little kid. That this isn't surgery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to hear that. Don't tell me you want to hear that shit!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes I do. Did you ever think that maybe I could help you? That maybe that's the point, that we're a team?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What, you want to come in here and save me? Is that what you want to do? Do I have a sign that says "save me" on my back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to "save" you. I just want to be with you. I love you. I love you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bullshit me! Don't fuckin' bullshit me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing up to him) You know what I want to hear?  I want to hear that you don't love me. If you tell me that, then I'll leave you alone. I won't ask any questions and I won't be in your life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SKYLAR'S DORM -- NIGHT Will leaves pulling on his clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NATIONAL SECURITY AGENCY, OFFICE -- DAY Will sits across from two N.S.A. AGENTS, OLIVER DYTRESS and ROBERT TAVANO. These guys are smug, clean cut, gung-ho and looking sharp in twin navy blue suits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will bites his tongue, trying to make this work.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So why do you think I should work for the National Security Agency?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you'd be working on the cutting edge. You'd be exposed to the kind of technology you couldn't see anywhere else because we've classified it. Super string theory, Chaos Math, Advanced algorithms--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Codebreaking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's one aspect of what we do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, that's what you do. You handle more than eighty percent of the intelligence workload. You're seven times the size of the C.I.A.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's exactly right, Will. So the question as I see it isn't "why should you work for N.S.A." it's "why shouldn't you?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why shouldn't I work for the National Security Agency? That's a tough one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CHUCKIE'S HOUSE -- DAY Chuckie, Billy, and Will sit in the Sullivan kitchen. Billy cracks open a beer and Chuckie reads the sports page. Both boys are smoking. Will drinks a beer, distractedly. We hear the faint music track and soft moans of a PORNO MOVIE emanating from a back room. After a beat, Chuckie looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a beat, Morgan comes out of the back room, red-faced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will pays no attention to this exchange
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Morgan, if you're watchin' pornos in my mom's room again I'm gonna give you a fuckin' beatin'!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (innocently) What's up guys?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you beat off at your house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have a VCR at my house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SOUTH BOSTON PAY PHONE -- DAY Will is on pay phone talking to Skylar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I just wanted to call before you left. (beat) I'm takin' all these job interviews. So I won't just be a construction worker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I never cared about that. An awkward beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will hangs up. Hold on him for an agonizing beat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you, Will. (pause) No take-backs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SEAN'S OFFICE -- DAY Lambeau is scribbling away at work. Tom is taking notes. Will is tapping his fingers, waiting for him to finish.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can... I'm almost there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Skylar stands at the gate, carry-ons in hand. Her flight is boarding. She looks for Will over the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will picks up a FRAME from Sean's desk. It is CARLTON FISK'S BASEBALL CARD. Will has to smile. Lambeau looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will can see that Lambeau wants more.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you smiling at?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a Carlton Fisk baseball card.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pudge Fisk. You follow baseball?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The final boarding call is announced and the last passenger boards. After a beat, Skylar turns and gets on the plane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will, holding the card, reflects for a beat and puts it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lambeau is excited. Will clearly is not.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, well, it's just somethin' Sean told me. It's a long story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You all set?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got the first part. The rest I can do at home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will, the N.S.A. has been calling me just about every hour. They're very excited about how the meeting went.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SEAN'S OFFICE -- NIGHT Will sits across from Sean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Will has obviously been stewing on this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Will says nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean gets up, goes to the door and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will loses it, slams the door shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean has finally gotten to Will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean lets this play out. Possible "shepard" change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Will looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean goes to the door and opens it. Will walks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So you might be working for Uncle Sam.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gerry says the meeting went well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did I think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say I'm working at N.S.A. Somebody puts a code on my desk, something nobody else can break. So I take a shot at it and maybe I break it. And I'm real happy with myself, 'cause I did my job well.  But maybe that code was the location of some rebel army in North Africa or the Middle East. Once they have that location, they bomb the village where the rebels were hiding and fifteen hundred people I never had a problem with get killed. (rapid fire) Now the politicians are sayin' "send in the Marines to secure the area" 'cause they don't give a shit. It won't be their kid over there, gettin' shot. Just like it wasn't them when their number got called, 'cause they were pullin' a tour in the National Guard. It'll be some guy from Southie takin' shrapnel in the ass.  And he comes home to find that the plant he used to work at got exported to the country he just got back from. And the guy who put the shrapnel in his ass got his old job, 'cause he'll work for fifteen cents a day and no bathroom breaks. Meanwhile my buddy from Southie realizes the only reason he was over there was so we could install a government that would sell us oil at a good price. And of course the oil companies used the skirmish to scare up oil prices so they could turn a quick buck. A cute, little ancillary benefit for them but it ain't helping my buddy at two-fifty a gallon. And naturally they're takin' their sweet time bringin' the oil back and maybe even took the liberty of hiring an alcoholic skipper who likes to drink seven and sevens and play slalom with the icebergs and it ain't too long 'til he hits one, spills the oil, and kills all the sea-life in the North Atlantic. So my buddy's out of work and he can't afford to drive so he's got to walk to the job interviews which sucks 'cause the shrapnel in his ass is givin' him chronic hemorrhoids.  And meanwhile he's starvin' 'cause every time he tries to get a bite to eat the only blue-plate special they're servin' is North Atlantic scrod with Quaker State.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what'd I think?  I'm holdin' out for somethin' better. I figure I'll eliminate the middle man. Why not just shoot my buddy, take his job and give it to his sworn enemy, hike up gas prices, bomb a village, club a baby seal, hit the hash pipe and join the National Guard? Christ, I could be elected President.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think you're alone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you have a soul-mate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Define that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone who challenges you in every way.  Who takes you places, opens things up for you. A soul-mate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shakespeare, Neitzche, Frost, O'Connor, Chaucer, Pope, Kant--
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're all dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not to me, they're not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you can't give back to them, Will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not without a heater and some serious smelling salts, no...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I'm saying, Will. You'll never have that kind of relationship in a world where you're afraid to take the first step because all you're seeing are the negative things that might happen ten miles down the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, what? You're going to take the professor's side on this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't give me your line of shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't want the job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not about that job. I'm not saying you should work for the government. But, you could do anything you want. And there are people who work their whole lives layin' brick so their kids have a chance at the kind of opportunity you have. What do you want to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't ask for this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody gets what they ask for, Will. That's a cop-out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why is it a cop-out? I don't see anythin' wrong with layin' brick, that's somebody's home I'm buildin'. Or fixin' somebody's car, somebody's gonna get to work the next day 'cause of me. There's honor in that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right, Will. Any man who takes a forty minute train ride so those college kids can come in in the morning and their floors will be clean and their trash cans will be empty is an honorable man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And when they get drunk and puke in the sink, they don't have to see it the next morning because of you. That's real work, Will. And there is honor in that.  Which I'm sure is why you took the job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just want to know why you decided to sneak around at night, writing on chalkboards and lying about it. (beat) 'Cause there's no honor in that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something you want to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you come back when you have an answer for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you won't answer my questions, you're wasting my time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the fuck are you to lecture me about life? You fuckin' burnout! Where's your "soul-mate?!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dead! She dies and you just cash in your chips. That's a fuckin' cop- out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I been there. I played my hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. And you fuckin' lost! And some people would have the sack to lose a big hand like that and still come back and ante up again!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at me. What do you want to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You and your bullshit. You got an answer for everybody. But I asked you a straight question and you can't give me a straight answer. Because you don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MAGGIORE BUILDER'S CONSTRUCTION SITE -- DAY Will and Chuckie take crowbars to a wall. This is what they do for a living. As they routinely hammer away, Will becomes more involved in his battle with the wall. Plaster and lathing fly as Will vents his rage. Chuckie, noticing, stops working and takes a step back, watching Will. Will is oblivious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SEAN'S OFFICE -- DAY Lambeau and Tom are in his office. Will is nowhere to be seen. Lambeau is on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up. Tom picks up a FORM up off the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A blank look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom understands, begins filling out the form.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What I mean, Sean, is that I'm sitting in your office and the boy isn't here. (beat) Well, it's ten past three. (beat) An hour and ten minutes late. (beat) Well, if he doesn't show up and I have to file a report saying he wasn't here and he goes back to jail, it won't be on my conscience, Sean. (beat) Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What should I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The boy was here. He came in, sat down and we worked together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He came in, sat down, and we worked together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HANRAHAN'S PACKAGE STORE -- LATER Will walks out carrying a brown bag. He is filthy, having just knocked off work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuckie is sitting on the hood of his Cadillac, watching Will across the street. Chuckie is covered in grime as well. Will starts walking towards Chuckie. As he draws closer, he heaves a can of Budweiser a good thirty yards, to Chuckie who handles it routinely. Will takes a seat next to Chuckie and they crack open their beers. Other workers file out of the site. They drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will holds an envelope which he slips in Sean's mailbox. He puts the flag up and smiles as he looks up at Sean in his apartment who is still unaware that Will is there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuckie pulls up in front of Will's house. He honks the horn, waits a beat, then gets out and heads toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will drives away from Sean's house. Sean hears the car pull out and looks out the window. Sean sees Will's car pulling away. Curious, he investigates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuckie walks up Will's front steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean walks out to the sidewalk and looks around. Seeing the mailbox flag has been raised, he walks over to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chuckie knocks on Will's front door. There is no answer. He waits a beat, looks in the window. An incredulous smile slowly starts to form.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean opens the card Will left for him. It reads:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in writing) Sean -- If the Professor calls about that job, just tell him, "Sorry, I had to go see about a girl."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Chuckie walks back towards his car unable to contain the broad smile. He knows Will is gone. He shrugs in explanation to the guys. Morgan takes Will's seat as they pull away from the curb.
direction.name: direction
